column1: Anal fissures are very common in infants, but they may occur at any age.
In adults, fissures may be caused by passing large, hard stools, or having diarrhea for a long time.

Other factors may include: - Decreased blood flow to the area in older adults - Too much tension in the sphincter muscles that control the anus Anal fissures are also common in women after childbirth and in persons with Crohn's disease.
Anal fissures may cause painful bowel movements and bleeding.
Other symptoms may include: - A crack in the anal skin that can be seen when the area is stretched slightly (the fissure is almost always in the middle) - Constipation
The health care provider will perform a rectal exam and look at the anal tissue.

If the anal fissures do not go away with home care methods, treatment may involve: - Botox injections into the muscle in the anus (anal sphincter) - Minor surgery to relax the anal muscle - Prescription creams such as nitrates or calcium channel blockers, applied over the fissure to help relax the muscles
